Let <math display="inline">\mathcal{S}_{n} = \left\{ x : x \in \left\{ a, b, c \right\}^{n}  \right\}</math> be the set of &lt;math&gt;{a, b, c}&lt;/math&gt; -strings of length &lt;math&gt;n&lt;/math&gt; not having &lt;math&gt;a b c&lt;/math&gt; as a substring.

Given a string <math display="inline">X = x_1x_2\ldots x_{n-1}x_{n}</math> for any <math display="inline">l,k \in \left[ n \right]</math>, we say that <math display="inline">x_{l}\ldots x_{k}</math> is a substring of <math display="inline">X</math>

For the empty tuple <math display="inline">\left(  \right)</math> , we will write <math display="inline">\epsilon</math>

Let <math display="inline">n \in \mathbb{N}^{\ge3}</math>, we wil parition <math display="inline">\mathcal{S}_{n}</math> by it’s last character, and count recursively, so let <math display="inline">s \in \mathcal{S}_{n}</math>

* If <math display="inline">s</math>’s last character is <math display="inline">a</math> or <math display="inline">b</math>, they could have been generated by <math display="inline">\mathcal{S}_{n-1}</math> and then appending an <math display="inline">a</math> or <math display="inline">b</math> to the end so there would be <math display="inline">2  \cdot \mathcal{S}_{n-1}</math> such strings * If <math display="inline">s</math>’s last character is <math display="inline">c</math>, then it could the two characters that appear before it must not be <math display="inline">ab</math>, so let’s count how many valid strings of <math display="inline">\mathcal{S}_{n-1}</math> do not end in <math display="inline">ab</math>. The number of strings that do end in <math display="inline">ab</math> can be generated by <math display="inline">\mathcal{S}_{n-3}</math> and then adding <math display="inline">ab</math> to the end, as appending <math display="inline">ab</math> to the end could never generate the substring <math display="inline">abc</math>. So the number of valid strings ending in <math display="inline">c</math> is <math display="inline">\mathcal{S}_{n-1}- \mathcal{S}_{n-3}</math>, in total we have that <math display="block">t_{n}=2  \cdot t_{n-1} + \left( t_{n - 1} - t_{n-3}\right)  = 3 \cdot t_{n-1} - t_{n-3}</math>

In the following calculations we will require that <math display="inline">n \ge 3</math>, so by hand we obtain <math display="inline">t_{0}=1</math> for <math display="inline">\epsilon</math> <math display="inline">t_{1}=3</math>, <math display="inline">t_{2}=3^{2}=9</math>

To compute <math display="inline">t_{8}</math> we use a bottom up approach

<math display="inline">t_{3}=3  \cdot t_{2} - t_{0}= 27 -1 =26</math> <math display="inline">t_{4}=3 \cdot t_{3} - t_{1}=3 \cdot 26  - 3=3  \cdot 25 =75</math> <math display="inline">t_{5}=3 \cdot t_{4} - t_{2}=3 \cdot 75  - 9= 225 - 9 = 216</math> <math display="inline">t_{6}=3 \cdot t_{5} - t_{3}=3 \cdot 216  - 26= 648 - 26= 622</math> <math display="inline">t_{7}=3 \cdot t_{5} - t_{3}=3 \cdot 216  - 26= 648 - 26= 622</math>

Let <math display="inline">n \in \mathbb{N}</math>, and choose <math display="inline">\left\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \right\rfloor + 2</math> distinct natural numbers, then we will always have a pair of numbers who’s sum or difference is disivible by <math display="inline">n</math>

Let <math display="inline">n \in \mathbb{N}</math> and <math display="inline">S \subseteq \mathbb{N}, \left| S \right|= \left\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \right\rfloor + 1</math> * We define the following set <math display="inline">X_n=\left\{ \left{ a, b \right}: a, b \in \left\{ 0, \ldots, n-1 \right\} \text{ such that  } a + b = n \right\}</math> and we claim it’s length is <math display="inline">\left\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \right\rfloor + 1</math> (add proof) * If <math display="inline">n =2k</math> for some <math display="inline">k \in \mathbb{N}</math> then <math display="inline">\left| X_{n} \right|=k + 1</math> * If <math display="inline">n =2k + 1</math> for some <math display="inline">k \in \mathbb{N}</math> then <math display="inline">\left| X_{n} \right|= \left\lfloor \frac{2k + 1}{2} \right\rfloor + 1=\left\lfloor k  + \frac{1}{2} \right\rfloor + 1=k + 1</math> * Recall that <math display="inline">\left\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \right\rfloor=k</math>

Consider the function <math display="inline">f : S \to X_{n}</math> such that <math display="inline">f\left(x\right)</math> is the set in <math display="inline">X_{n}</math> that contains <math display="inline">x</math>’s remainder mod <math display="inline">n</math>, since <math display="inline">\left| S \right|= k + 2</math> and <math display="inline">\left| X_{n} \right|=k + 1</math> then by the pigeon whole principle we have <math display="inline">x, y \in S</math> such that <math display="inline">f\left(x\right)=f\left(y\right)</math> if <math display="inline">x</math> and <math display="inline">y</math> have the same remainder mod <math display="inline">n</math> then their difference is a multiple of <math display="inline">n</math> (namely it is zero), if <math display="inline">x</math> and <math display="inline">y</math> have a different remainder, since they reside within the same two element their sum is equal to <math display="inline">n</math> so the sum of <math display="inline">x</math> and <math display="inline">y</math> is a multiple of <math display="inline">n</math> .

A self map is a function who’s domain is the same as it’s codomain

an injection is a function <math display="inline">f : X \to Y</math> such that <math display="block">\forall x, y \in X, f\left(x\right)=f\left(y\right)\implies x=y</math>

A surjection is a function <math display="inline">f : X \to Y</math> such that <math display="block">\forall y \in Y, \exists x \in X, \text{ such that  } f\left(x\right)=y</math>

Note that <math display="inline">\left( A \times B \right) \times C \cap A \times \left( B \times C \right)</math> as an element from the left hand side would have the form <math display="inline">\left( \left( \cdot, \cdot \right), \cdot \right)</math> and the one on the right <math display="inline">\left( \cdot, \left( \cdot, \cdot \right) \right)</math>

Additionally, for a given set <math display="inline">X</math> we may write <math display="inline">X^{n}</math> to represent the set <math display="inline">\left\{ \left( x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_{n-1}, x_{n} \right): \forall i \in \left[ n \right]x_{i} \in X \right\}</math>, the notation is suggestive of <math display="inline">\underbracket{X \times X \times \ldots \times X}_{n\text{ times }}</math>
